langUsage.language: French as written in the 17th century

editorialDecl.p: The language of most of the letters in this collection is Middle French, as documented by the Dictionnaire de l'Académie française of 1694 and Jean Nicot's Thresor de la langue françoyse, tant ancienne que moderne of 1606. Both of these dictionaries may be accessed through the University of Chicago ARTFL Project Dictionnaires d'autrefois. Additionally, a short guide by Thomas Luckett at Portland State University might be helpful to readers who are not familiar with the 17th century French: Reading Old Regime French.

Essential as these resources are to deciphering the letters in this archive, they also do reveal the extent to which French orthography, letter formation, and punctuation were not yet standardized in the first half of the 17th century. Spelling was phonetic and varied, even within a single document and even for proper nouns. When formed by hand, the letters "f" and "s," "p" and "q," "r" and "t" were often indistinguishable, making consideration of the context of the surrounding letters and words essential. Commas were nearly non-existant, and full-stop punctuation was often omitted, especially at the ends of lines. The informality and assumed privacy of the epistolary form may have only encouraged these ambiguities and variations.

The archival letters in this collection are either hand-written documents in manuscript or are letters transcribed and printed in the seventeenth century. In the modern transcriptions of the print letters, elements that have more to do with page design than the original (lost) manuscript letters have not been retained. These include line breaks, soft end-of-line hyphens, the all-caps presentation of opening and closing salutations, running heads, letter titles, page numbers, and page signatures. In the transcriptions of manuscript letters, line breaks and elements of page layout have been retained to the extent possible, to facilitate the coordinated reading of facsimile and transcription. It should be noted that, for all transcriptions, a computerized search of a word will not return instances of that word when it was hyphenated in manuscript.
In all of the transcriptions, of both early modern print and manuscript letters, original spelling and punctuation have been retained, with the following exceptions for correction and normalization:

correction.p: Correction. In the semi-diplomatic view, two types of correction have been made silently: First, known abbreviations have been expanded, as with Mr./Monsieur, S.M./Sa Majesté, and V.E./Vostre Eminence. Second, in words that have been connected to a preceding article or pronoun, apostrophes have been added, as with daffection/d'affection, nest/n'est, and mescrire/m'escrire.

Any spellings that that are evident errors, in that they would lead to a mispronounciation of a known word, are highlighted in the transcription. Hovering over the highlighted word will prompt display of the corrected spelling.

Any words that are completely illegible are indicated with a bracked question mark. Words that are simply not recognizable as words have been transcribed to the extent possible and are immediately followed by question mark.

normalization.p: Normalization. In 17th century paleography and typography, "u" and "v" were two forms of the same letter, which could serve as either a vowel or a consonant. Usually the v-form was used initially, while the u-form was used medially. Similarly, the letter "j" was usually represented by the "i," both at the beginning and in the middle of words.

In this archive, the user may choose to view either a "semi-diplomatic" transcription, which reproduces the u, v, i, and j just as they were written in the source text, or a "normalized" transcription, which converts each letter to its appropriate noun or verb form.

person.note: Camp marshal from 1635, governor of Provence from 1638. On the death of his father in 1650 he became Comte d’Auvergne and Duc d’Angoulême.
Keeper of the Seals (Garde des sceaux) of France from 1624 to 1635.
The favorite and most trusted advisor of Christine of France, duchess of Savoy, during her regency.
Officer and governor of Languedoc from 1633 to 1644. He was named marshal of France in 1637 in recognition of his victory at the Battle of Leucate.
Lawyer, counsellor of state, and inspector of French forces under Richelieu.
French general instrumental in restoring Catholicism in the south-western provinces of Languedoc and Guyenne. He was made a duke and named ambassador to Poland by Louis XIV.
A writer of popular epistolary essays and founding member of the Académie française.

person.persName: Bernard de Nogaret de La Valette, 2e duc d’Épernon
person.note: French general, brother of Cardinal de La Valette, and Richelieu’s nephew by marriage. While serving under the Prince de Condé in the Seige of Fuenterrabía of 1638, he refused to lead an attack after the town walls had been breached. For this he was tried and sentenced to death for military negligence in 1639. Bernard had already fled to England, however, where he lived until the end of Louis XIII’s reign. He returned to France in 1643, when the judgement against him was cancelled by the Parliament of Paris (Moote, p. 251; Levi, pp. 383–5.
First president of the parliament of Toulouse, from 1632 until at least 1649. In 1632 he was instrumental in putting down the rebellion of Henri II de Montmorency.
Wife of Claude Bouthillier, comte de Chavigny. She was entrusted with the education of Richelieu’s orphaned niece (Tapié, p. 394).
Charles I reigned from 1625 until his execution in 1649. In 1625 he married Henrietta Maria of France, sister of Louis XIII.
Duke of Savoy from 1580 to 1630, succeeded by his son, Victor Amadeus I.

Second son of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy, and Christine of France. His inheritance of the duchy at the age of 4 on the death of his brother Francis Hyacinth was challenged by his uncles Thomas, prince of Carignano, and Maurice, prince of Savoy.

person.persName: Gaspard III de Coligny, marquis de Chatillon
person.note: Huguenot general known for his loyalty to Louis XIII, named marshal of France in 1622.

Chavigny was appointed secretary of state by Richelieu in 1628 and superintendant of finances in 1632, offices he held until the death of Louis XIII in 1643. He lead many diplomatic missions, often accompanied by Père Joseph.

Sister of Louis XIII and wife of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy. At the duke’s death in 1637 she became regent, first in the name of her son Francis Hyacinth (d. 1638), then in the name of her second son, Charles-Emmanuel II. Her regency was challenged by her brothers-in-law Thomas, prince of Carignano, and Maurice, prince of Savoy, in the Piedmontese Civil War.

person.persName: Henri II de Bourbon, prince de Condé
person.note: Senior member of the cadette branch of the House of Bourbon during the reign of Louis XIII. From 1611 until the birth of Louis XIV in 1638 he was second in line to the throne of France, behind Louis’ brother, Gaston d’Orleans.

Son of a printer who entered the French military at age 14 and was recognized for his bravery and engineering skill at La Rochelle (1627–28) and several other sieges throughout the 1630s. He served in the Piedmont regiment, was made governor of Sedan in 1642 and marshal of France in 1658, the first commoner to earn that distinction.

person.persName: Eleonora Gonzaga, princess of Mantua and Holy Roman Empress
person.note: Empress from 1622 until the death of Ferdinand II in 1637. The deaths of her three brothers without heirs instigated the War of Mantuan Succession, 1628–1631, with Phillip IV of Spain and Charles Emmanuel I of Savoy allied against Louis XIII and Venice.

person.persName: Antoine III, duc de Garamont, comte de Guiche
person.note: French military commander and diplomat known for his loyalty to Richelieu. For his service in the Thrity Years’ War he was named marshal of France in 1641.
Member of a banking family from Lucca and advisor to Richelieu.

person.persName: Jean-Louis de Nogaret de La Valette, 1e duc d’Épernon
person.note: First duke of Épernon and father of Henri (d. 1639), Bernard (2nd duke of Épernon), and Louis, Cardinal de La Valette.
Vice-admiral instrumental in putting down a Huguenot rebellion at La Rochelle in 1622, named Marshal of France in 1627.

Former page of Louis XIII sent on a diplomatic mission to Holland at the age of 19. His diplomatic and military service would continue into the reign of Louis XIV, who would name him marshal of France in 1675.

person.persName: Francois Annibal de Coeuvres, maréchal d’Estrées
person.note: Peer of France named marshal of France in 1626. After his military career he entered diplomacy, serving as French envoy to Rome from 1636 to 1648.

person.persName: Ferdinando II de Medici, granduca di Toscana
person.note: Grand-Duke of Tuscany from 1621 to 1670; friend and protector of Galileo Galilei.
Ferdinand III reigned from 1637 to 1657.

person.persName: Maria Gonzaga, duchess of Mantua and Monferrat
person.note: Gonzaga and her husband, Charles of Nevers, inherited the duchies of Mantua and Monferrat in 1627. Challenges to the inheritance instigated the War of the Mantuan Succession, 1628–31.
Pope from 1621 to 1623, he elevated Richelieu to cardinal in 1622, calling him the “rampart of Catholic religion and the scourge of heretics” (Blanchard, p. 116).

person.persName: Henri de Lorrain, comte de Harcourt
person.note: French nobleman who entered military service in 1620 at the siege of Prague. Along with the Vicomte de Turenne, he would lead the combined Piedmontese-French forces in the Piedmontese Civil War, and would win the city of Turin for France after a three-month-long triple siege.
Eldest son of the first duke of Épernon and brother of Bernard and Louis, Cardinal de La Valette. On Henri’s death in 1639, his brother Bernard would inherit the title.

person.persName: Henrietta Maria, queen consort of Charles I, king of England
person.note: Sister of Louis XIII, king of France. Her marriage to Charles I was negotiated by Richelieu, who at the time was an equal member in the king’s council. The negotiation is regarded as Richelieu’s first diplomatic success (Levi, p. 81).
Scottish soldier of fortune appointed commander of the Scots Brigade by Cardinal de La Valette in 1636. He was killed in Lorraine in 1637 while serving under Chatillon.

person.persName: Francois de l’Hospital, comte du Hallier
person.note: Youngest son in an aristocratic family who renounced the religious life to pursue a military career at the age of 15. He represented Louis XIII at the 1628 signing of articles of capitulation ending the siege of La Rochelle and serve in several campaigns of the Thirty Years’ War.

person.persName: François Leclerc du Tremblay, père Joseph
person.note: French Capuchin friar, friend and advisor to Richelieu, unofficial negotiator with German states, and the original “eminence grise.” His willingness to ally France with Protestant powers against Catholic Spain prevented his elevation to cardinal, despite Richelieu’s efforts (Blanchard, pp. 125 and 270, n. 21).

person.persName: Diego Felipe de Guzmàn, marquis de Leganès
person.note: Cousin of the Count of Olivares, first minister to Philip IV of Spain and, as of 1635, captain general and governor of the Duchy of Milan. He was active in the Piedmontese Civil War, 1639–41.

person.persName: François de Bonne, duc de Lesdiguières
person.note: Leader of the Huguenot resistance in Dauphiné, he served under the future Henry IV from the 1580s and would be named marshal of France by that king in 1609. He was loyal to Louis XIII and, after converting to Catholicism in 1622, was named constable of France.

person.persName: Henri II d’Orléans, duc de Longueville
person.note: A legitimated prince and peer of France and favorite of Marie de’Medici who facilitated her revolt in 1620. In 1648 he would head the French delegation at the Treaty of Westphalia.

The second Bourbon king, Louis ascended the throne at the assassination of his father Henry IV in 1610, and in 1617 forcibly ended the regency of his mother, Marie de’Medici. Considered a suspicious and insecure ruler, Louis relied on a succession of competing advisors and favorites, most notably Richelieu.
Son of Louis XIII and Anne of Austria, “le Roi Soleil” reigned from 14 May 1643.

Grand Falconer of France, advisor and companion of Louis XIII during the regency. He convinced the young king to end the regency of his mother, Marie de’Medici, in a palace coup in 1617. Named constable of France in 1621, he died of a fever that same year while laying siege to the Huguenot stronghold of Montauban.

person.persName: Maria Anna, empress consort of Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor
person.note: Infanta of Spain, she married the Austrian Hapsburg Ferdinand Ernest, future Holy Roman Emperor, in 1626. Richelieu opposed this strengthening of the alliance between the Spanish and Austrian branches of the Hapsburg family (Tapié, p. 296).

person.persName: Marie de’Medici, queen consort of Henry IV, king of France
person.note: Second wife of Henry IV, crowned queen of France the day before the king’s assassination in 1610. In 1617 she was forced from power by her son, Louis XIII, and expelled to Blois. Though she reconciled with Louis and returned to court in 1621, her attempt to end Richelieu’s influence in 1630 on the “Day of the Dupes” would result in her permanent exile, first to Brussels, then to Amsterdam.

person.persName: Maurizio, prince and cardinal of Savoy
person.note: Brother of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy. On the death of the duke in 1637, Maurice and his brother Thomas, prince of Carignano, attempted to take the regency from Christine of France, inciting the Piedmontese Civil War.

Jesuit priest appointed ambassador to the court of Louis XIII by Victor Amadeus, duke of Savoy, in 1631. By arguing for the elevation of the duchy to a monarchy and disputing to claims of France to territories within Savoy, Monod aroused the wrath of Richelieu; to preserve relations with France Victor Amadeus recalled the minister and placed him under house arrest in Cuneo (Coni). From there Monod secretly plotted with the Spanish governor of Milan against Richelieu and France and attempted to flee Savoy. In January of 1639 at Richelieu’s urging, Christine, duchess and regent of Savoy, resentfully imprisoned Monot in the castle of Montmélian (Tapié, p. 390). At a later date Richelieu would transfer Monod to the fortress-prison of Miolans, where he would remain until his death.

person.persName: Hercule de Rohan, duc de Montbazon
person.note: Peer of France who served Henry III and Henry IV; he was riding in the carriage when Henry IV was assassinated in 1610. His daughter Marie would become the infamous Madame de Chevreuse, conspirator in the courts of Louis XIII and Louis XIV.

Godson of Henri IV, governor of Languedoc, and a leading figure at the court of Louis XIII. As grand admiral and marshal of France he put down several Huguenot rebellions and won victories against Spain in the Piedmont. In 1632 he joined Gaston d’Orleans in a failed attempt remove Richelieu from power. Ignoring pleas for mercy throughout France, Richelieu executed Montmorency as an example to other members of his class.

person.persName: François Sublet de Noyers, Baron de Dangu
person.note: Secretary of state for war from 1636 and a loyal creature of Cardinal Richelieu.
Son of Maximilien de Béthune, duc de Sully.

person.persName: Philippe de Clerembault, comte de Palluau
person.note: Officer of noble birth who would rise from captain of a company of light horsemen in the 1630s to marshal of France by 1653.
Hapsburg king who reigned from 1621 to 1640 and allied with the Austrian Hapsburgs against France in the Thirty Years’ War, 1618–48.

person.persName: César de Choiseul, comte du Plessis-Praslin
person.note: Military officer and diplomat, named ambassador to the court of Victor Amadeus I of Savoy in 1630. He was active in the Piedmontese Civil War, named governor of Turin in 1640, and marshal of France in 1645.

person.persName: Antoine de L’Age, Duc de Puylaurens
person.note: Confidant and advisor to Gaston, duc d’Orleans. Puylaurens was arrested in 1635 for aiding Gaston’s escape from France in the aftermath of a failed attempt to remove Richelieu from power, and for facilitating the politically unfavorable marriage of Gaston to Marguerite of Lorraine. Puylaurens died at Vincennes after seven months of imprisonment (Blanchard, pp. 151–53).

person.persName: Armand-Jean du Plessis, cardinal duc de Richelieu
person.note: First minister to Louis XIII from 1624 to 1642. Richelieu would strengthen the monarchy by reducing the influence of the nobility and disarming the Huguenots; he would make France the ascendant power in Europe by mid-century by allying with Protestant nations against the Catholic Hapsburgs.
Member of an aristocratic Savoyard family.

person.persName: Maximilien de Béthune, duc de Sully
person.note: Protestant favorite of Henry IV, Chief minister and from 1589, and superintendent of finances from 1600 until Henry’s assassination in 1610. Sully helped to bring financial stability to France after the wars of religion, put down Huguenot rebellions, encouraged agriculture, and rebuilt infrastructure.
Counselor of state from 1631 and secretary to Cardinal de La Valette.

person.persName: Pons de Lauzières, marquis de Thémines
person.note: Member of the court of Henry IV and supporter of Marie de’Medici during the regency, named Marshal of France in 1616. In 1619 Thémines’ son Antoine would kill Henri du Plessis, older brother of the future Cardinal Richelieu, in a duel.

Brother of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy. On the death of the duke in 1637, Thomas and his brother Maurice, prince of Savoy, attempted to take the regency from Christine of France, inciting the Piedmontese Civil War.

person.persName: Henri de la Tour d’Auvergne, vicomte de Turenne
person.note: French military general instrumental in defeating the forces of Prince Thomas in the Piedmontese Civil War. He was named marshal of France in 1643 and later marshal general.
Pope from 6 August 1623 to 29 July 1644.

person.persName: Louis de Nogaret, cardinal de La Valette
person.note: Cardinal and lieutenant general in the French army, brother of Henri de Nogaret, duc de Candalle and Bernard de Nogaret, duc d’Épernon as of 1642.

person.persName: Victor Amadeus I, duc de Savoie
person.note: Duke of Savoy from 1630–37, married to Christine of France, sister of Louis XIII. The duke’s death in 1637 and the death of his eldest son, Francis Hyacinth, in 1639 instigated the Piedmontese Civil War, as the regency of Christine was challenged by the late duke’s brothers, Thomas, prince of Carignano and Maurice, prince of Savoy.

occupation.desc: Secretary to Richelieu, cousin of the secretary Cherré.

person.note: Secretary to Richelieu, cousin of the secretary Cherré.

occupation.desc: Canon of Notre Dame de Paris, prior of Abbaye des Roches, and secretary to Richelieu, especially for ecclestiastic, financial, and personal affairs.

person.note: Canon of Notre Dame de Paris, prior of Abbaye des Roches, and secretary to Richelieu, especially for ecclestiastic, financial, and personal affairs.

occupation.desc: Secretary to Richelieu, cousin of Charpentier

Identity unknown.

place.note: Commune in the Grand Est region of northeastern France, in the former province of Champagne.
Commune in the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy, about 55 km from Turin.
Commune in Brittany on the northwestern coast of France.

Town about 30 km west of Turin that would be won by the French in July of 1630. Upstream from the French possession of Casale, Avigliana (Veillane) was considered by Louis XIII to be of great strategic importance to France (Moote, p. 214).
Town outside of Bern, Switzerland.
Town at the juncture of Provence, the Piedmont, and Dauphiné, claimed alternately by France and Savoy in the 16th and 17th centuries.
Commune in Southern France, about 10 km from the Mediterranean.
Town in northeast Savoy.
Town in northwestern France, about 25 km from Nantes.
One of traditional provinces of France, in the southeast along the Pyrenees.
Lowland region of Savoy that was ceded to France by the 1601 Treaty of Lyon and later became part of Burgundy.
Town in the Loire Valley with a small, dry-moated castle.
Commune in north-central France.
Town in the western part of Southern France, in the Occitane region.
Town outside of modern-day Turin claimed by France in the 16th century, besieged and conquered by Savoy in 1588, and taken back by France during the Piedmontese Civil War.

Fortified town in the Piedmont, about 60 km east of Turin. By the 1635 Treaty of Rivoli with the dukes of Savoy and Parma, France would occupy Casale and Pinerolo as a defense against Spanish encroachment from Milan (Tapié, p. 330).
Former capital of Savoy in the northwest of the duchy. The capital was moved to Turin in 1563 as a defense against French encroachment.
Village in Brittany in northwestern France, about 25 km from Rennes.
A town about 20 km northeast of Turin that submitted to Prince Thomas after a short siege in late March of 1639.
A traditional province of France, in the southeast bordering on Savoy and the Piedmont.
Town in northern France.
Commune in the Piedmont of strategic importance to Savoy and frequently besieged by France in the 17th century, about 90 km south-west of Turin.
Town in the province of Vercelli, in the Piedmont, about 35 km northeast of Turin.
City in eastern France.
County of the Netherlands under Spanish Hapsburg control in the 17th century.
Town in the modern province of Cuneo, about 40 km south of Turin.

place.placeName: Château de la Grange des Prés
Château de la Grange des Prés
place.note: Estate of the Dukes of Montmorency, north of Pézenas in Languedoc-Roussillon, Southern France. In July of 1629 Henri II Montmorency hosted Richelieu at the château.
Capital of the traditional province of Dauphiné in southeastern France, at the foot of the French Alps.
Town in the Piedmont about 50 km northwest of Turin.
Town in the province of Dauphiné, near the 17th century border with Savoy.
A traditional province of France, now Occitane, with the capital city Toulouse.

Huguenot stronghold on the western coast of France; site of a rebellions in 1622 and 1625. In 1627 Richelieu organized a blockade of the city and construction of a massive seawall to obstruct relief ships from England; La Rochelle surrendured 14 months later.
Rural area of the Piedmont 100 km west of Turin, near the modern border with France.
Town north of Spain on the Mediterranean coast of France.

Duchy in northern Italy that passed from the Gonzaga to the French Gonzaga-Nevers in 1627. Rival claims backed by Savoy and Spain resulted in the War of Mantuan Succession, 1628–31, which ended favorably for France.
Town about 8 km south of Turin.
A former official residence of the House of Savoy in the metropolitan city of Turin, first built in the 12th century to command southern access to the city.
Commune in the Bourgogne region of France.
City in south-central France, historically a banking center and, from the Renaissance, a center of book publishing and silk production.
A traditional province of France, north of Languedoc and west of Dauphiné, with the capital city of Lyon.
A quarter of Turin northwest of the city center.
City in Lorraine, in northeastern France near Luxembourg.
Village in the Asti region of Piedmont, about 45 km east of Turin.
A former duchy on the east side of the Piedmont, a portion of which was gained by Savoy in the War of the Mantuan Succession, 1628–31.
Fortified castle in Savoy constructed from the 11th to 18th centuries.
Town in the Rhône department of southeastern France.
Commune in the Occitane region about 15 km from the Mediterranean.
City on the French Riviera under the protection of Savoy in the 17th century.
City at the foothills of the Pyrénées, in Nouvelle-Aquitaine in Southern France.
Town in Languedoc, about 15 km west of Toulouse.

Fortified town in Savoy about 50 km southwest of Turin that came under French control in 1631. By the 1635 Treaty of Rivoli with the dukes of Savoy and Parma, France would occupy Pinerolo and Casale as a defense against Spanish encroachment from Milan (Tapié, p. 330).
Commune in the Île-de-France region of north-central France.
Part of the Escartons Republic, a semi-independent French state that was granted to Savoy by the 1713 Treaty of Utrecht.
A traditional province of France on the Mediterranean, bordering on the Piedmont to the west and Dauphiné to the north.
Commune in Brittany about 30 km from the coast.
Commune in the Turin metropolitan area, about 14 km west of the city center.
A former official residence of the House of Savoy in the Turin metropolitan area.
Town in the Vendée, the former province of Poitou, in western France.
Town located half-way between Louis XIII’s primary residence at Saint-Germain-en-Laye and Paris. Richelieu’s preferred residence from 1633 until his death in 1642 was at Rueil.
Town in the Loire Valley in western France.
Royal palace about 12 km west of Paris and a prinicpal residence of Louis XIII.
Town in the province of Vercelli, about 50 km northeast of Turin.
Town in the province of Cuneo, about 50 km south of Turin.
Town about 50 km west of Turin.
Valley of the Isère River, in the Savoy region of France.
City in the Piedmont and capital of the Duchy of Savoy in the 16th and 17th centuries.
Thirteenth century castle along the Po River in Turin, renovated and occupied by Christine, duchess of Savoy.
Mountainous region in northwestern Italy, part of Savoy in the 17th century.
Town in the Yonne department of Bourgogne-Franche-Comte, belonging to the house of Condé in the 17th century.
City in the Piedmont west of Turin, alternately conquered by France and Spain in the 16th to 18th centuries.
Town in western France in Nouvelle-Aquitaine, about 25 km from Richelieu, the cardinal’s ancestral home.
Town in the Province of Asti.
Town in the Turin metropolitan area.

body.p:
Si ce n’est Vostre Majesté qui m’assiste puissamment, ie je me voy succomber dans de grandes miseres par la perte de l’Estat, & elle tachée de reputation laissant perdre ceux qui, conioints conjoints à elle, & de sang, & d’interest, se sont détachés de tout autres parties pour estre entierement vnis unis aux siens, & sous sa protection ; Ie Je supplie Vostre Maiesté Majesté d’y apporter le plus prompt remede qu’elle iugera jugera pour l’ vn un & pour l’autre, & parce que l’Abbé de la Monta luy representera de ma part l’estat où ie je me trouue trouve ; Ie Je la supplie tres-humblement de ne laisser pas perir ceux qui la seruent servent
auec avec autant d’affection comme i j ’ay fait, afin d’encourager ceux qui ont les mesmes sentimens que moy à les suyure suyvre , comme ie je proteste que ma volonté est telle, pourueu pourveu qu’en me conseruant conservant le mien elle me donne le moyen de la mettre en effet, & faire paroistre de plus tous les iours jours en exposant ma vie comme i j ’ay fait que ie je suis auec avec toute sorte de sincerité.

closer.salute: Monsievr Monsieur , Vostre tres-humble, & tres- obeyssante sœur & seruante servante
closer.dateline: De Turin ce deuxiesme Auril Avril 1639.
